The graphics in the game are absolutely stunning, with the developers delivering an outstanding job on the environments. Although there are only eight main missions, most of them are very large and provide a great deal of gameplay flexibility, allowing for different approaches and tactics. During these moments, some limitations of the game‚Äôs AI became apparent. While the AI is generally solid and has clearly been adjusted to be forgiving (making stealth more enjoyable without requiring constant save-scumming) they can remain on high alert for an extended period after being triggered. There‚Äôs something here of Barry Pepper‚Äôs icy sprint in Saving Private Ryan, and something of that predatory silence in the ruins of Stalingrad from Enemy at the Gates‚Äîmoments when the very landscape becomes an adversary. This is a game that refuses to let you relax, even for a heartbeat.

Each mission unfolds like a new act in a grand wartime production, staged with an almost documentary devotion to the era. The locations are unique, diverse, and unforgiving in their own elegant ways.

You‚Äôll navigate coastal fortifications where the wind claws sound into shreds, and where every fold of terrain turns into a natural rampart or trap.
You‚Äôll move through French manors with shaded avenues and cold stone walls, behind which patrols, spotlights, and hidden routes are woven into a dark, intricate tapestry.
You‚Äôll infiltrate industrial districts where metal sings at the touch of the wind, and where the maze of warehouses and workshops operates like a multi-layered chessboard‚Äîone in which verticality matters as much as the horizontal plane.
You‚Äôll descend into ancient fortresses wrapped in heavy historical silence, where each corridor resembles the throat of a beast, and the shadows whisper of those who walked there before you.
You‚Äôll operate within coastal towns where promenades echo with distant footsteps, and where wealthy homes and narrow alleyways form a geometry of risk, refuge, and endless tactical permutations.

This is a world where the horizon is layered, where each hill is an opportunity, every tower a point of power, and every sound a potential fuse to your undoing.

In Sniper Elite 5, missions are not tasks‚Äîthey are wide, branching meadows of decisions.
Your entry point, your exit route, your elevation, pacing, distance‚Äîeverything belongs to you. The game seems to whisper, ‚ÄúChoose your path. Choose your rhythm. See how far you‚Äôre willing to go.‚Äù
They‚Äôre vast as a river in flood, yet precise and clockwork in their internal logic.

Playing on the highest difficulty becomes its own form of self-awareness.
Distance turns into a philosophical variable.
Wind becomes a fluctuation of fate.
A bullet becomes your signature under a decision you cannot retract.
Any step may be your last‚Äîyet it‚Äôs this fragility that creates the sense of truth. You feel every second, every breath, as if you were not in a game but in someone else‚Äôs war, compelled to see it through.

Sniper Elite 5 possesses a rare quality: it fuses you with your character.
With every mission you begin to feel the weight of the rifle, the cold edge of the scope beneath your fingers, the dry crackle of grass beneath your elbow. You start breathing in sync with this world‚Äîits winds, its echoes, its danger. And at some point, almost imperceptibly, you realize: you are no longer just playing.
You‚Äôve stepped onto that terrible page of history where everything‚Äîabsolutely everything‚Äîhinges on a single, solitary shot.

Best sniper saga I‚Äôve played ‚Äî powerful rifles, satisfying stealth, and flexible mission design. Full stealth and careful planning are rewarded with easier times, though one map forces melee-only stealth in a small linear spawn area.

Traps can be inconsistent near staircases, random enemy spawns feel unfair at times, and Schu-mines are mostly ineffective. Silenced rifles are DLC-only pre finishing the game, and base-game sniper upgrades require finding the workbench on each map. Early satchels are scarce, and you often need to finish the campaign to have them in your inventory to handle tanks, anti-air personnel, and optional objectives without hunting for satchels.

Overall it's still a fun entry, but feels somewhat confused. SE4 still felt like a Sniper Elite game that also happened to improve enough of the stealth mechanics to be played like a stealth game as a bonus. Comparatively, 5 feels like a stealth game that just happens to have Sniper Elite mechanics. That may not sound like a bad thing on paper, but it means I was looking at the stealth mechanics with more scrutiny and a lot of them feel very frivolous. Like, Rebellion just looked at a bunch of other stealth games over the past few years and went, "Oh yeah, add that in there," for the sake of it (MGSV probably being the biggest one).

The inclusion of a non-lethal playstyle sort of embodies the feeling of adding mechanics for the sake of having them. I'm usually not one to balk at more player choice in a stealth game, but in here it mechanically does not serve a purpose. You get LESS XP for knocking somebody out than using a lethal takedown (unless you intend to kill the enemy right after), both takedown types are quiet, you don't have to worry about something like a blood trail coming out of a corpse if relocating a body, and a patrolling enemy finding a body unconscious is identical to finding them dead (they'll check the body and become partially alerted). There are a lot of opportunities Rebellion could've taken to make non-lethal an actual ideal option depending on enemy layouts (have enemies immediately go for an alarm if they see a dead body, make lethal takedowns loud, etc.) and they took none of them. And of course narratively speaking (I know, it's Sniper Elite, who cares, shut up), it just doesn't make much sense at all because 5 takes place after 3 and 4. Karl has a corpse pile of god knows how many Nazis and fascists under his belt at this point in the war, why would he care now?

Also the levels in 5 are much larger than 4 which isn't a bad thing on its own, but it just makes it stick out incredibly hard when Karl is incapable of moving through invisible walls portrayed by bushes or a wall he should be very capable of mantling, because the developers wanted the player to go through more intended routes.

Still, at the end of the day, it's more Sniper Elite fun, if diluted a little ironically because of them attempting to add new features. The new Invasion mode at the very least is an actual fun inclusion that adds newfound tension that normally wouldn't be in the game otherwise.
